Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Research in Chemistry and Biochemsitry at Miami University
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Research Experience for Undergraduate Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Carole Dabney-Smith and colleagues at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio provide students with extensive, independent research experiences that are designed to develop and refine students' experimental skills and enhance their ability to work as part of a research team. The combination of active research, professional development, and cohort-building will provide the next generation of scientists with a well rounded experience and strong encouragement to continue in one of many areas of science as a career.

The project focuses on students underrepresented in chemistry and/or those who do not have opportunities for research at their home institution. Students will choose from research projects in analytical, biological, inorganic, organic, physical chemistry, and chemistry education research, with most projects being interdisciplinary, such as in the areas of bioanalytical, bio-inorganic, biophysical, and nanotechnology. Students will also participate in sessions that will cover a number of topics associated with professional development including (i) the development of research proposals and scientific presentations, (ii) understanding ethics in science and (iii) available career paths in chemistry and biochemistry, including science policy. Activities are designed to prepare students for various job opportunities for chemists and to build a strong cohort. Many undergraduate chemistry and biochemistry students often lack exposure to scientific research career opportunities or opportunities to apply critical thinking skills to open-ended research. The broader impacts of Miami University's Chemistry and Biochemistry REU program are to promote research in chemistry and biochemistry as a career, especially for students underrepresented in the physical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many undergraduate chemistry and biochemistry students often lack exposure to scientific research career opportunities or opportunities to apply critical thinking skills to open-ended research. The objective of Miami University's Chemistry and Biochemistry REU program was to promote research in chemistry and biochemistry as a career, especially for students underrepresented in the physical sciences. Our ten-week summer program focused on three primary areas: (1) development/enhancement of research skills, (2) professional development including exposure to research career opportunities beyond academics, and (3) cohort/team building. Together these were designed to stimulate students' interest in chemical research and prepare them for graduate school or careers in chemistry/biochemistry related fields.

 Our REU site award at Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, provided extensive independent research experiences designed to develop/refine students' experimental skills and enhance their ability to work as a part of a research team. Students chose from cutting edge research projects in analytical, biological, inorganic, organic, physical chemistry, and chemistry education research, with most projects being interdisciplinary, such as bioanalytical, bio-inorganic, biophysical, and nanotechnology. Students also participated in sessions that covered several topics associated with professional development including the development of research proposals, scientific presentations, ethics in science, careers in chemistry and biochemistry including science policy, and a few social activities to build a strong cohort. The combination of intense research, professional development, and cohort building provided the next generation of scientists with a well-rounded experience and strong encouragement to continue in one of many areas of science as a career.

 The proposed program was designed for students underrepresented in chemistry and/or do not have opportunities for research at their home institution. Recruitment efforts specifically targeted students from underrepresented groups and at least 50% of the participants were minority students. Participation in a diverse collaborative group benefitted all participants and encouraged students to pursue careers in chemistry and biochemistry, thus diversifying the pool of professionals. Students and mentors participated in a variety of activities reinforcing the concept of the group as a community of scholars. These activities help prepare students for careers in science or science policy but also better equip them as good citizens.
